constructs.name: weekend_work_intensity
constructs.description: Amount of work-related browsing activity on weekends (Saturday and Sunday) - the behavior we want to reduce

constructs.name: weekday_work_volume
constructs.description: Total work-related browsing activity on weekdays (Monday-Friday)

constructs.name: weekday_leisure_volume
constructs.description: Leisure and personal browsing activity on weekdays - indicates work-life balance

constructs.name: late_evening_work
constructs.description: Work activity occurring after 8pm - indicates boundary blurring between work and rest time

constructs.name: night_activity
constructs.description: Any browsing activity between midnight and 5am - indicates sleep disruption or shifted schedule

constructs.name: technical_research_intensity
constructs.description: Density of deep technical browsing - captures intellectual engagement that may spill into weekends

constructs.name: stress_wellbeing_signal
constructs.description: Searches related to mental health, stress, sleep, or self-medication - signals potential burnout

constructs.name: vacation_travel_mode
constructs.description: Active travel or vacation period - external context that should reduce work tendency

constructs.name: last_activity_hour
constructs.description: Hour of final browsing activity each day - late cessation indicates poor sleep opportunity

constructs.name: first_activity_hour
constructs.description: Hour of first browsing activity each day - indicates wake time and morning routine

constructs.name: browsing_category
constructs.description: Topic category of browsing - aggregated diversity indicates scattered vs focused attention

constructs.name: work_engagement_momentum
constructs.description: Latent weekly state representing accumulated pull toward work activities

constructs.name: baseline_workaholic_tendency
constructs.description: Stable individual tendency toward overwork - person-level trait

edges.description: High weekday work volume indicates demanding periods that spill into weekends
More weekday leisure indicates better boundaries, reducing weekend work
Habitual late evening work indicates blurred boundaries that extend to weekends
Night owl patterns indicate disrupted rhythms and poor boundaries
Deep technical engagement creates cognitive momentum that pulls you back on weekends
Stress drives compensatory overwork or indicates burnout requiring catch-up
Being on vacation forces disconnection, reducing weekend work
Later daily cessation indicates poor boundaries that extend to weekends
Earlier wake times may indicate structured routine protecting weekends, or higher pressure
Higher category diversity indicates scattered attention, potentially reducing deep work spillover
Later bedtimes lead to fatigue and reduced next-day productivity
Chronically late bedtimes shift schedule, normalizing late work the next day
Night-time browsing directly extends last activity hour
Working late pushes bedtime later, leading to post-midnight browsing
Working late directly increases last activity hour
Late bedtime leads to sleeping in the next morning
High sustained workload creates stress and prompts wellness searches
Stress leads to anxiety-driven extended work hours
Absorption in engaging problems causes losing track of time
More daytime breaks may require catching up in evening
Higher category diversity includes more leisure topics
Deep technical focus reduces category diversity (stays in fewer categories)
Stress and anxiety keep you up later
Being on vacation naturally reduces work browsing
Vacation increases leisure browsing
Accumulated weekly engagement predicts weekend work propensity
Deep dive episodes build engagement momentum
Higher weekday work feeds into engagement momentum
Stable trait influences how quickly engagement builds
Workaholic tendency manifests as regular late evening work
